Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 7 nodes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and 9 edges A->C, B->F, B->D, B->G, C->F, C->G, D->F, D->E, F->G.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents market demand, B represents talent, C represents education level, D represents quality of teaching, E represents wheather condition, F represents rainfull and G represents work-life balance.
Background.data_info: For those with talent being high, the probability of quality of teaching being high is 0.0673. For those with talent being low, the probability of quality of teaching being high is 0.4298.

Instruction: Consider the average treatment effect (ATE) of talent on quality of teaching.
Question: If talent is changed to be high, will quality of teaching be more likely to be high?

Reason.Step 1: Check whether treatment (B) is a cause of outcome (D). Node B is a cause of node D because there is one or more directed paths from B to D (e.g. B->D).
Reason.Step 2: Identification of the Causal Effect. P(D|do(B)) can be identified.
Reason.Step 3: Find a valid backdoor adjustment set: empty set.
Reason.Step 7: ATE=-0.3625<0 so the answer is No.

given_info: Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: Market demand has a direct effect on education level. Talent has a direct effect on rainfull. Talent has a direct effect on quality of teaching. Talent has a direct effect on work-life balance. Education level has a direct effect on rainfull. Education level has a direct effect on work-life balance. Quality of teaching has a direct effect on rainfull. Quality of teaching has a direct effect on wheather condition. Rainfull has a direct effect on work-life balance.
